text: Nanotubes are extensions of cell envelopes that connect the cytoplasm or periplasm between two different cells.
Unfortunately, viruses can generate nanotubes in their host cells in order to transmit progeny viruses to a new cell without exposure to the immune system.
In Gram-negative enteric bacteria, pili of a different kind, also called the sex pili, attach a “male” donor cell to a “female” recipient cell conjugation.
Bacillus subtilis bacteria with intercellular connections called nanotubes, which pass material from one cell to the next.
In a favorable habitat, such as a running stream full of fresh nutrients or the epithelial surface of a host, it is advantageous for a cell to adhere to a substrate.
Adherence, the ability to attach to a substrate, requires specific structures.
For example, the sexually transmitted pathogen Neisseria gonorrhoeae uses pili to attach to the mucous membranes of the reproductive tract (Fig.
Nanotubes can transmit materials from one cell to another—even between cells of different species.
shows how nanotubes interconnect cells of Bacillus subtilis.
Structures that connect the cells’ cytoplasm include intercellular nanotubes.
The genetic consequences of conjugation are discussed in Chapter 9.
also called fimbria (plural, fimbriae), which is constructed of straight filaments of protein monomers called pilin.
